Developing efficient catalysts for the synthesis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) from biomass resources is very demanding as it is an important renewable platform chemical for the synthesis of biofuels, polymers and fine chemicals. Here, we have designed two new crystalline microporous bi-functional porous organic polymers through the extended aromatic substitution reaction under refluxing conditions. Porous polymers containing sulfonic acid and secondary amine groups are two reactive catalytic centres for carrying out the bi-functional heterogeneously catalysed reactions. Bifunctionalized porous polymers POPDS and POPSDS are synthesized through the reaction of 2,2′-benzidinedisulfonic acid and 4,4′-diaminostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid with cyanuric chloride, respectively. The materials were characterized thoroughly using powder X-ray diffraction, N2 sorption, FTIR, solid state 13C CP MAS NMR spectroscopy, FE-SEM, HR-TEM, XPS and TG/DTA analysis. These two crystalline porous polymers possesses good surface acidic and basic sites, and having flower-like and spherical particle morphologies. POPDS and POPSDS exhibited superior catalytic activity for the conversion of different small carbohydrates to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) under microwave irradiation. Moreover, the recyclability tests of these catalysts revealed good durability up to sixth consecutive reaction cycles, suggesting the future potential of these catalysts in the sustainable synthesis of HMF. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Microporous organic polymers Bi-functionalized catalysts Fructose 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Microwave assisted synthesis 1 Introduction With the progressive raise in the population and industrialization over the decades, non-renewable fossil fuel resources are going to diminish in the future and this could cause climate and atmospheric changes as well as huge energy crisis. Several alternative synthetic routes are undertaken over the years in search of renewable and sustainable energy resources [1–5]. Thus, the design and synthesis of environmentally benign catalysts for the conversion of earth abandoned biomass to the value-added chemicals like 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), which is a platform chemical for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals [6], biofuels like 2,5-dimethylfuran (2,5-DMF) [7–9], polymers [10] etc. is very challenging. HMF can be synthesized through the acid catalysed dehydration of carbohydrate obtained from the naturally available biomass. Among the carbohydrate-based biomass resources, fructose is most common feedstock for the synthesis of HMF. Over the years, many organic and inorganic acids such as HCl, H3PO4, p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA), methanesulfonic acid (MSA) have been used as homogeneous catalysts and they show good catalytic activity as well as selectivity in the synthesis of HMF [11–13]. However, there are some limitations during separation of pure product from the reaction mixture containing these homogeneous catalysts, corrosion to the reaction flask and lack of reusability of the catalyst. These have motivated the researchers to focus on novel functionalized heterogeneous catalyst for HMF production. In general, the catalytic dehydration reaction can be carried out by using various types of catalysts such as mixed metal oxides [14,15], Brønsted or Lewis acid catalysts [16–18], zeolites [19] etc. Further, bi-functional carbonaceous catalyst bearing acid-base sites facilitate this one-pot conversion of carbohydrates to HMF quite efficiently [20]. Thus, bi-functional porous solids bearing both acidic and basic sites at the catalyst surface could be an efficient strategy for carrying out the HMF synthesis from the biomass resources. Furthermore, the catalytic efficiency of heterogeneous solid catalyst is largely dependent on other important factors, like specific surface area, access of the reactive catalytic sites to the substrate, morphological feature and favourable pore opening [21–23]. Specifically, porous organic polymers (POPs) are fascinating materials in this context and showed excellent application potentials in catalysis [24–26], gas storage [27,28], energy storage [29] and so on. Different chemical routes like solvothermal [30], Schiff base condensation [31], C-C homo and cross-coupling reactions [32], radical polymerization [33], involving a wide range of organic building blocks are employed for the synthesis of these POPs. Polymeric framework bearing active organic functional groups can amplify the application potential of these porous organic materials. Moreover, the existence of in-built -SO3H and –NH- groups in the polymer matrix could make larger number of accessible catalytic sites avoiding the post-synthesis random sulfonation or amination route. Introduction of a large number of -SO3H and –NH- groups inside the microporous channel of polymers can accelerate the performance of the catalyst together with its high product yield. Crystalline POPs synthesized through the substitution of the chloride atoms of cyanuric chloride by aromatic amines can offer robustness in the framework due to long-range periodic nanostructure. We hereby report two new sulfonic acid and secondary amine functionalized crystalline microporous organic polymers POPDS and POPSDS through the extended substitution/polymerization of 2,2′-benzidinedisulfonic acid and 4,4′-diaminostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid with cyanuric chloride under refluxing condition at inert atmosphere. The combination of both acidic and basic groups in the crystalline polymer matrix with a narrow microporous channel, could make these porous materials as efficient heterogeneous bi-functional catalysts for HMF synthesis from the earth abandoned biomass resources under microwave assisted heating conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals 2,2′-Benzidinedisulfonic acid (MW = 344.36) and 4,4′-diaminostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid (MW = 370.39) were purchased from TCI Chemicals. Potassium carbonate (MW = 138.205 g/mol), cyanuric chloride (MW = 184.4 g /mol), and anhydrous 1,4-dioxane were also obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. All the organic solvents used for the washing purpose were directly used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of porous polymers In a typical synthetic procedure, 3 mmol (1.003 g) of 2,2′-benzidinedisulfonic acid was dissolved in 25 mL 1,4-dioxane. To this solution, 2 mmol (0.368 g) of cyanuric chloride was poured and stirred for 20 min under nitrogen atmosphere. Then, 6 mmol (0.829 g) of potassium carbonate was added into the reaction mixture as a weak base and subjected to continuous stirring under refluxing condition at 130 °C temperature for 72 h. After the completion of the reaction, the white solid product was obtained via simple filtration and washed with the organic solvents like ethanol, dioxane, and acetone. The as-synthesized product was dried for overnight and denoted as POPDS. Another porous polymer POPSDS had been synthesized by reacting 3 mmol (1.111 g) of 4,4′-diaminostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid with 2 mmol (0.368 g) of cyanuric chloride in 1,4-dioxane. Similarly, potassium carbonate was added to this reaction mixture and allowed to reflux for 72 h under inert condition. The off-white-coloured product was obtained after filtration and washed with ethanol, dioxane and acetone to remove any excess reacting monomers from the material surface. The as-synthesized product was dried for overnight and denoted as POPSDS. The schematic route for the synthesis of POPDS and POPSDS polymers and their respective pore models are shown in Scheme 1 . These two materials have been characterized thoroughly using different characterization tools. 2.3 HMF synthesis The dehydration of fructose into HMF was monitored employing the thin layer chromatographic (TLC) method by using methanol-chloroform mixture as solvent, where the solvent ratio was 1: 10 (v/v). After the successful catalytic reaction the liquid product was solvent extracted using ethyl ether for three times. Finally, the pale yellow colored liquid product was collected and characterized by using liquid 1H, 13C NMR analysis in CDCl3 solvent for confirming the synthesis of pure liquid HMF. The non-existence of brown colored liquid in the resulting HMF product suggested that there was very negligible amount of decomposition products levulinic and formic acids as well as polymerization of carbohydrate to humic acids, under the reaction conditions. For synthesizing the pure HMF from different types of hexoses, like monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, galactose, mannose), disaccharide (sucrose), and polysaccharides (cellulose, cellobiose), some important steps like hydrolysis of ester, isomerization of hexoses, and fructose dehydration reaction, were carried out over these bi-functionalized catalysts. In a typical catalytic reaction fructose (0.25 mmol) and the POP catalyst (20 mg) was taken in a 10 mL glass vessel containing anhydrous DMSO (4 mL). The small magnetic stirring bar was placed inside the vial to make the reaction mixture homogeneous during the reaction. Then the reaction vial was put inside the microwave reactor and the reaction parameters like temperature, heating and cooling time of the vial was controlled. After the completion of the reaction, resultant reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature and it was subjected to extraction with diethyl ether solvent. The resultant product was obtained after evaporating the organic solvent through the rotary evaporator and the purity of final oily product was affirmed by using 1H, 13C NMR spectroscopy technique in CDCl3 solvent. To estimate the conversion of fructose and yield of HMF was performed by using HPLC apparatus Agilent 1200 Series and this was equipped with XDB-C18 column. The fructose conversion (mol%) as well as yield of HMF (mol%) were obtained as follows: Conversion of fructose (%) = Fructose consumption (mole)/ Initial fructose (mole) x 100 Yield of HMF (%) = HMF formed (mole)/ Initial fructose (mole) x 100 2.4 Instrumentation FTIR spectra of the porous polymers were obtained from Thermo Scientific Nicolet 4700 spectrometer in the reference of KBr pellet. Wide-angle powder X-ray diffraction patterns for two porous organic polymers were measured through RIGAKU Rint 2000 diffractometer with monochromatic Cu-Kα (0.15406 nm) radiation (40 mA, 40 kV). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of two polymers were analyzed using Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ where 150 °C temperature was used for outgassing purpose for 12 h. Pore size distribution plots have been estimated using NLDFT (non-local density functional theory) method. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of these samples were obtained from Hitachi SU-8000 SEM, where accelerating voltage was 15 kV. The solid-state 13C CP-MAS NMR spectra of these materials were measured using 11.74 T Bruker Advanced-II spectrometer 99.5 MHz NMR instrument equipped with a 4 mm MAS probe and 11 KHz spinning rate, where contact time and relaxation delay were 1.5 ms and 5 s respectively. The materials (5 mg) were dispersed in absolute dry ethanol by ultra-sonication and one drop of that dispersed solution mixture was allowed to fall vertically on the carbon-coated portion of copper grid, which was subjected for drying before TEM (transmission electron microscopy) analysis under vacuum conditions. The HR-TEM images of the materials were recorded by using JEOL 2010 TEM, which was operated at 200 kV. Further, adsorption of static water test was conducted to investigate the nature catalyst surfaces, which revealed that the catalysts are hydrophilic in nature [39]. The catalytic activities of these two microporous organic polymers have been evaluated in the synthesis of HMF from various types of hexoses. The conversion of fructose has been measured under microwave assisted heating conditions in five solvents e.g. N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), tetrahydrofuran (THF), dichloroethane (DCE) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) for optimizing the ideal solvent. Notably, other reaction parameters are very important to acquire the best HMF yield for synthesis of HMF and these are the reaction time, temperature, and catalyst amount. To understand the effect of reaction time, the fructose conversion reactions have been performed using fructose (0.25 mmol) in DMSO with 20 mg of catalyst by varying the reaction time from 10 to 30 min. The time dependent HMF product yield has been plotted in Fig. 9 a. Notably, the high product yield (86% and 89%) was achieved after 25 min reaction time at 130 °C temperature over POPDS and POPSDS catalysts (1H and 13C NMR of HMF products are shown in Fig. S1-S4). Since, reaction temperature is most important parameter for obtaining maximum HMF product yield, the fructose conversion reactions are carried out from 110 to 150 °C temperature range over POPDS and POPSDS catalysts. After completion of reaction, the maximum HMF product yield was found to be 86 and 89% at 130 °C temperature, whereas other parameters were remained unchanged. Fig. 9 b represents the HMF product yield (%) vs. temperature, where the product yield was increasing with rising the temperature up to 130 °C. Beyond this optimum temperature (130 °C), the product yield was decreasing due to the further catalytic reaction leading to levulinic acid, formic acid and humic acid. Additionally, high temperature can be the driving force for polycondensation of HMF product, which produces insoluble humins and polymers. The loading amount of catalyst is one of the crucial parameters for HMF synthesis from biomass. Similar representative reactions have been carried out to optimize the exact catalyst loading amount for obtaining high product yield by varying the amount from 0 to 30 mg. Fig. 9 c represents the plot of HMF product yield against catalyst loading amount, where the maximum yield (86 and 89%) was obtained after 20 mg of catalyst loading. With increasing amount of the catalysts loading beyond 20 mg, no change in product yield was observed, suggesting no improvement of the catalytic reaction beyond optimum catalyst loading. Similar observation was reported by Hu et al., where decomposition and degradation of HMF could be facilitated in the presence of additional amount of catalyst during conversion of fructose [40]. On the other hand, in the absence of catalyst, the HMF product yield was very low keeping other reaction parameters same. This result suggested truly catalytic nature of these bifunctional catalysts. To find out the best solvent for fructose conversion reaction, the same model reactions have been performed using five different solvents such as DMSO, DMF, THF, DCE, and NMP. Fig. 9 d represents the HMF yield vs. solvent profile, where the yield was maximum in case of DMSO. Even though, water is designated as environmentally friendly solvent, still DMSO was used as a best solvent for the HMF synthesis due to poorer product yield in aqueous phase. The higher yield of HMF in DMSO due to the larger tangent value (tan δ), which suggested that higher electromagnetic energy can be converted into the heat energy at definite frequency. To our knowledge, the tangent value of anhydrous DMSO is found to be 0.825, which is larger in comparison with the, DMF (0.166), THF (0.047), DCE (0.048), and NMP (0.038). Preferably, DMSO has higher tangent value, which means higher absorbing capability of microwave electromagnetic energy in comparison with other aforementioned solvents. In addition, the coordination of DMSO with the HMF will be dominated by the strong interaction between the solvent containing oxygen atoms and the HMF bearing carbon atoms. This leads to the stronger binding HMF with DMSO [41–43]. Although fructose is most superior feedstock among other biomasses, we have carried out this carbohydrate conversion reaction on easily available glucose to HMF due to the limited access and high-cost associated with fructose. To determine the intervening reaction steps, the conversion of glucose was carried out at two temperatures (130 and 120 °C) without changing the standard reaction parameters. The product yield was found to be 67% and 56% which are lower than that from fructose due to the intermediate step i.e. isomerization of glucose. Moreover, the synthesis of HMF from glucose is very challenging due to its stable six-membered ring isomerization followed by the dehydration process ( Scheme 2 ). In addition to that, dehydration reaction of disaccharide and polysaccharide biomass have been carried out for the synthesis of HMF under optimized reaction conditions. In dehydration reaction of sucrose, the hydrolysis process was occurred to obtain the glucose and fructose. In second step, ring isomerization of glucose can form the fructose unit which can undergoes elimination reaction of water in final step. Thus, the obtained HMF product yield was lower (55% and 58%) from sucrose than that from monosaccharide (fructose and glucose). In the conversion of fructose, HMF is the predominant product together with secondary products like levulinic acid, formic acid and humic acid. Observed side product yield is below 5% of the main product. Under this selected condition, the reaction kinetics of the fructose conversion will be the pseudo-first order reaction [44]. This reaction kinetics further confirms that the rates of the fructose dehydration reaction over bifunctionalized POPDS and POPSDS catalyst were 1.86 × 10−4 and 1.93 × 10−4 mmol s−1 at 130 °C temperature, respectively. XPS and FTIR spectra reveals that the presence of desired framework elements and organic functional groups, which provides the surface acidic and basic sites. Interestingly, large amount of surface acidic and basic sites of two catalysts are the driving force for the synthesis of HMF and this is quite evident from the NH3 and CO2-TPD analyses. Further, the high activity of these catalysts could be attributed to the considerably good specific surface area as well as porous nature of the catalyst. Notably, microwave heating irradiation method is entirely different from the convention oil bath heating conditions due to the high heating rate as well as selective heating of the molecules through the whole reaction at a time. Further, it also decreases the activation energy and increase the pre-exponential factor of the Arrhenius equation due to orientation effect of polar substrate in the electromagnetic field [45,46], which facilitates the fructose conversion greatly over conventional heating process. In conventional heating process, the surface of the substrate is heated first and gradually the heat will transfer to the core. To check the reusability of the catalysts, the representative fructose conversion reactions have been performed for six times under optimum reaction conditions. The catalyst was washed with diethyl ether after completion of each reaction to remove the previously obtained product from the catalyst surface. To activate the used catalyst for next time, the catalyst was dried in 60 °C oven. Fig. 10 displays the reusability plot of HMF product yield vs. number of reaction cycles, where the negligible amount of HMF was decreased after six consecutive reaction cycles, suggesting the good recycling efficiency of the catalyst. To check the stability in structural morphology, FE-SEM and HR-TEM images of reused POPDS and POPSDS catalysts are shown in Fig. S5. As seen from these images that the morphologies of these porous polymers remained unchanged after catalytic reactions under microwave heating conditions. This result suggested the good structural stability of these porous polymer catalysts and their sustainable catalytic applications. Further, we have performed the wide-angle powder XRD analysis (Fig. S6) of reused POPDS and POPSDS catalysts, where the crystalline planes are similar to that of the fresh catalysts. This result suggested that these crystalline porous catalysts have good structural stability after several consecutive reaction cycles. Among various natural sources of HMF synthesis, fructose is the most preferred feedstock, however its natural occurrence is limited. This calls for an alternative source for HMF synthesis like carbohydrates, glucose, and sucrose. The conversion of glucose to HMF likely proceeds through successive steps- mutarotation and isomerization of glucose to fructose and fructose dehydration to HMF [51]. Generally, isomerization of glucose to fructose is aided by base catalysts [52]. A proposed mechanism for glucose to HMF conversion over POPDS and POPSDS catalysts has been shown in Scheme 3 . The basic nature of this bifunctional catalysts is due to the presence of amine moieties, which catalyses the isomerization step. Possibly through a hydride transfer, the intermediate A gets converted to ketohexose B, which eventually gets converted to fructofuranose via cyclization. Over the years, it has been observed that an acid catalyst is necessary for the dehydration of saccharides to HMF [53]. In our case, the presence of Brønsted sulfonic acid-sites serve as a proton source, which facilitates the conversion of fructofuranose to HMF, as discussed by Chen et al. [54]. Moreover the intermediate C was identified by NMR studies in dehydration of D-fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [55], which supports the formation of C in our proposed mechanism. Finally, the HMF is formed through the loss of one water molecule from the intermediate C. 4 Conclusion Two new crystalline microporous organic polymers have been synthesized through the extended aromatic substitution reaction between the cyanuric chloride and 2,2′-benzidinedisulfonic acid or 4,4′-diaminostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid under refluxing conditions. Presence of the secondary amine as well as sulfonic acid group makes these porous polymers as efficient bi-functional heterogeneous catalyst having reactive Brønsted basic and acidic sites. Good BET surface area together with in-built -SO3H and –NH- groups in these materials are responsible for their high catalytic activity for the conversion of biomass derived fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural having product yield of 86-89 mol% in DMSO. The catalysts exhibit excellent reusability up to sixth consecutive reaction cycles without any significant loss of product yield, suggesting the future potential of these crystalline porous polymers in a wide range of acid catalysed reactions. coredata.dc:description: Developing efficient catalysts for the synthesis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) from biomass resources is very demanding as it is an important renewable platform chemical for the synthesis of biofuels, polymers and fine chemicals. Here, we have designed two new crystalline microporous bi-functional porous organic polymers through the extended aromatic substitution reaction under refluxing conditions. Porous polymers containing sulfonic acid and secondary amine groups are two reactive catalytic centres for carrying out the bi-functional heterogeneously catalysed reactions. Bifunctionalized porous polymers POPDS and POPSDS are synthesized through the reaction of 2,2′-benzidinedisulfonic acid and 4,4′-diaminostilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid with cyanuric chloride, respectively. The materials were characterized thoroughly using powder X-ray diffraction, N2 sorption, FTIR, solid state 13C CP MAS NMR spectroscopy, FE-SEM, HR-TEM, XPS and TG/DTA analysis. These two crystalline porous polymers possesses good surface acidic and basic sites, and having flower-like and spherical particle morphologies. POPDS and POPSDS exhibited superior catalytic activity for the conversion of different small carbohydrates to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) under microwave irradiation. Moreover, the recyclability tests of these catalysts revealed good durability up to sixth consecutive reaction cycles, suggesting the future potential of these catalysts in the sustainable synthesis of HMF.
